case_vignette:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician because he has excessively dry skin. His mother says that he has had dry, scaly skin since he was 6 months old. She says it is worse in winter and better in summer. There is no associated itching, redness, or discharge. Examination reveals generalized fine scales with coarse skin all over the body, except in the skin creases of the neck and in the cubital and popliteal fossae (see image). There are multiple papular elevations at the base of hair follicles and darkening of the palmar and plantar creases.  A) Eczema B) Psoriasis C) Seborrheic dermatitis D) Keratosis pilaris
Answer: D) Keratosis pilaris
Explanation: Keratosis pilaris is a benign condition characterized by the appearance of small, rough, sandpapery papules on the skin, especially on the arms and legs. It is caused by the accumulation of keratin in the hair follicles. The condition is more common in children and is often associated with dry skin. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with keratosis pilaris. Eczema (atopic dermatitis) is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by itchy, red, and scaly skin. Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune condition characterized by thick, scaly skin. Seborrheic dermatitis is a condition characterized by a red, itchy, and scaly rash, often on the scalp, face, and torso. None of these conditions match the patient's symptoms and physical examination findings.

Examination reveals generalized fine scales with coarse skin all over the body, except in the skin creases of the neck and in the cubital and popliteal fossae (see image). There are multiple papular elevations at the base of hair follicles and darkening of the palmar and plantar creases.  A) E
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have excessively dry, scaly skin which I've had since I was very young. It gets worse in the winter and better in the summer.
Do you have any relatives with similar skin conditions, or any other types of skin disorders?
No, there is no mention of any relatives with similar skin conditions or other types of skin disorders.

No, there is no mention of any other skin conditions or chronic health issues.

I am 8 years old, and the symptoms were first noticed when I was 6 months old.
Final Diagnosis: Ichthyosis Vulgaris.
